system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

system_message:

You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.

- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on.

  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.

- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it.

You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

reasoning_content:
We are in a room with a machine and 8 objects (0 to 7) initially on the floor.
 The machine's light is off. We need to figure out which objects are blickets and the rule (conjunctive or disjunctive).

 Since the previous attempts to put object0 and object1 failed with "object0 is not a recognized object", it seems there might be a misunderstanding in the command format.

 Let me check the initial description: "object 0 is on the floor", so the object is referred to as "object 0" (with a space). But in the command, we must use the exact reference.

 The initial look says: "object 0", "object 1", etc. So the command should be: `put object 0 on machine`

 However, note that in the previous interaction, when I said "put object0 on machine" it said "object0 is not a recognized object", but when I said "put object 0 on machine" it worked: "You put object 0 on the machine."

 So I should use the format with a space: "object 0", "object 1", etc.

 Current state: object 0 is on the machine, and the machine light is off.

 Next, I need to test more objects.

 Strategy: 
 Since the rule could be conjunctive (all blickets required) or disjunctive (any blicket turns it on), I should start by testing individual objects to see if any turn the machine on by themselves.

 If I find an object that turns the machine on by itself, then the rule is disjunctive and that object is a blicket. But if none do, then it might be conjunctive.

 However, note the tip: "You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. 'conjunctive' rule)."

 So let's test each object one by one on the machine and observe the light.

 But note: we have 8 objects and limited steps (32). We can do this efficiently.

 Step 1: We have already put object 0 on the machine -> light off.

 Now, I'll test object 1.

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

reasoning_content:
We are in a room with a machine and 8 objects (0 to 7) initially on the floor.
 The machine's light is off.
 We need to figure out which objects are blickets and the rule (conjunctive or disjunctive).

 Important: The tips say to first consider the conjunctive rule (all blickets must be on the machine for it to turn on).

 However, note that in the previous attempts, when I tried to put object0 and object1, the system said they are not recognized? 
 But looking at the initial description: "object 0 is on the floor", etc. So the objects are named with a space? 

 But in the error messages, when I tried "put object0 on machine" it said "object0 is not a recognized object", and similarly for "object1". 
 Then I tried "put object 0 on machine" and it worked: "You put object 0 on the machine." 

 So the correct way is to include a space between "object" and the number.

 Let me start by putting one object on the machine to see if it turns on.

 Since the machine didn't turn on when I put object 0 on, I now have object 0 on the machine and the light is still off.

 Next step: I should try putting another object to see if the machine turns on. But I need to be systematic.

 Considering the conjunctive hypothesis: if the rule is conjunctive, then we need all blickets on the machine to turn it on. 
 So if I put all objects on the machine and it turns on, then I can start removing objects to see which ones are necessary.

 However, with 8 objects and limited steps (32), I must be efficient.

 Alternatively, I could try a different approach: test each object individually to see if any single object turns the machine on (which would indicate disjunctive rule). 

 But note: the tips say to first consider conjunctive. However, if the rule is disjunctive, then putting one blicket on should turn the machine on.

 So let's test each object one by one.

 Since object 0 is already on the machine and the machine is off, we know that if the rule is disjunctive, object 0 is not a blicket.

 Now, I will put the next object (object 1) on the machine.

 Command: put object 1 on machine

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.

reasoning_content:
We are in a room with 8 objects (0 to 7) and a machine. The goal is to identify which objects are blickets and the rule (disjunctive or conjunctive) that makes the machine turn on.

Initial state: All objects are on the floor, machine light is off.

I have tried to put object0 and object1 on the machine, but the commands were not recognized properly. The system says "object0 is not a recognized object" when I tried "put object0 on machine" and similarly for object1.

Looking at the valid command examples, perhaps the object names are without space? Or maybe the command should be exactly as per the format.

In the initial description, it says: "object 0 is on the floor", so the object names are "object 0", "object 1", etc. with a space.

But in the command I tried "put object 0 on machine" and it worked: "You put object 0 on the machine." But the machine light is still off.

Then I tried "put object1 on machine" without space and it said not recognized.

So the correct way is to use "object 0", "object 1", etc.

Now, I have object 0 on the machine. Machine light is off.

I need to test other objects.

But note: I have 32 steps, and I've already used several invalid commands, so I must be efficient.

Strategy:

Since the rule could be conjunctive (all blickets must be on) or disjunctive (any blicket turns it on), I should start by testing individual objects to see if any single one turns on the machine.

If I find one that turns on the machine by itself, then it is a blicket and the rule is disjunctive? Not necessarily, because in conjunctive rule, one object alone wouldn't turn it on, but if I put all and it turns on, then I know conjunctive.

But if I put one and it turns on, then the rule must be disjunctive (since one blicket is enough) and that object is a blicket.

If I put one and it doesn't turn on, it could be: either it's not a blicket, or it is a blicket but the rule is conjunctive so more are needed.

So to disambiguate, I need to test combinations.

But to save steps, I should test one object at a time first.

Currently, object 0 is on the machine and light is off. So either object 0 is not a blicket, or it is but the rule requires more.

Now I should try putting another object on the machine.

Let me try object 1.

But first, let me make sure the command is correct.

Command: "put object 1 on machine"

If the machine turns on, then at least one of object 0 or object 1 is a blicket? Not necessarily, because if object 1 is a blicket and rule is disjunctive, then putting it on could turn it on even if object 0 is not. But if rule is conjunctive, then putting object 1 alone might not turn it on, but with both, it might if both are blickets and that's all.

But currently, object 0 is already on, so if I put object 1 on, then both are on. If the machine turns on, it could be because both are blickets and rule is conjunctive, or because at least one is and rule is disjunctive.

To distinguish, I would need to test each alone.

But I haven't tested object 0 alone: I put it and machine didn't turn on. So if object 0 were a blicket and rule disjunctive, the machine should have turned on when I put it. But it didn't, so either object 0 is not a blicket, or the rule is conjunctive.

Similarly, if I put object 1 alone and it doesn't turn on, same for it.

But if I put both and it turns on, then:

- If rule is disjunctive: at least one of them is a blicket (and since individually they didn't turn on, that would be a contradiction? Because if disjunctive, putting a blicket alone should turn it on. But if individually they didn't, and together they do, that suggests the rule is conjunctive and both are blickets.

Exactly.

So if I put object 0 alone -> no light
Then put object 1 alone -> no light
Then put both -> light on: then conjunctive rule and both are blickets.

If when I put object 1 alone, the light turns on, then disjunctive rule and object 1 is a blicket (and object 0 is not, because when alone it didn't turn on).

But in this case, I haven't tested object 1 alone yet

reasoning_content:
We are in a room with a machine and 8 objects (0 to 7). The goal is to determine which objects are blickets and the rule (disjunctive or conjunctive) that makes the machine turn on.

From the interaction history:
- I tried to put object0 on the machine and the command was accepted: "You put object 0 on the machine. The light on the machine is currently off."
- However, when I tried "put object0 on machine" (without space) it said "object0 is not a recognized object". Similarly for object1 without space.
- It seems the system expects the object name with a space, like "object 0", not "object0".

But note: the initial description says "object 0", "object 1", etc., so we must use the space.

Current state:
- I have put object 0 on the machine, and the machine light is still off.

Now, the question is: Is object 0 a blicket?

We have very limited information. We only put object 0 on the machine and the light did not turn on.

Considering the two rules:
- If the rule is conjunctive (machine turns on only when all blickets are on the machine), then having only one blicket (if object 0 is a blicket) would not turn on the machine because there might be other blickets missing. So the light being off does not tell us that object 0 is not a blicket.
- If the rule is disjunctive (machine turns on if at least one blicket is on the machine), then if object 0 were a blicket, the machine should have turned on. But it did not. Therefore, in the disjunctive case, object 0 is not a blicket.

However, note the tips: "You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. 'conjunctive' rule)."

Therefore, at this point, we cannot conclude that object 0 is not a blicket because the rule might be conjunctive and we haven't placed all blickets.

But we have no evidence that object 0 is a blicket either.

Given that we have only one data point, and the machine didn't turn on, we cannot be sure. However, the question is: based on the information we have, is object 0 a blicket?

In the disjunctive rule, we can conclude it is not. In the conjunctive rule, we don't know. But note that we have not ruled out the conjunctive rule.

But the question is asking for a direct answer with True/False. We must output either True or False.

Given the information, we don't have enough to confirm it is a blicket, and we have a scenario (disjunctive) where it would have turned on if it were and it didn't, so we can say it's not a blicket? 

But wait, the tip says to consider the conjunctive rule first. However, the machine did not turn on with only object 0. If the rule were disjunctive, then object 0 is definitely not a blicket. If the rule is conjunctive, then object 0 might be a blicket but we are missing others.

But without knowing the rule, we cannot be sure. However, note that in the disjunctive case, the absence of the machine turning on when only object 0 is on means object 0 is not a blicket. In the conjunctive case, the same observation (light off) does not tell us about object 0.

But the problem says: "In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered 'blickets'." So in the conjunctive case, we don't know if object 0 is required until we test with all.

Given that we have only one test, we have no evidence that object 0 is a blicket. Moreover, we have a scenario (disjunctive) that would have given evidence if it were, and it didn't.

Therefore, based on the current information, we cannot say for sure, but the safe answer is that we have not observed it causing the machine to turn on by itself (which would be required in disjunctive) and we haven't seen it in combination. So we don't know.

But the question is: "Is object 0 a blicket?" and we must answer True or False.

Looking at the interaction, we only have one object on the machine and the light is off. We have not seen the machine turn on at all.

Given that we are to base the answer on the information we have, and we have no positive evidence for object 0 being a blicket, and in one rule (disjunctive) it would have turned on if it were, we can say it is not

system_message:
You are an intelligent, curious agent. You are playing a game where you are in a room with different objects, and a machine. Some of these objects are blickets. You can't tell which object is a blicket just by looking at it, but they have blicktness inside of them. Blicktness makes the machine turn on, following some hidden rule.

Your goals are:
- Identify which objects are blickets.
- Infer the underlying rule for how the machine turns on. 

Here are the available commands:
  look:                describe the current room
  put ... on ...:      put an object on the machine or the floor
  take ... off ...:    take an object off the machine
  exit:                exit the game

Tips:
- All objects can be either on the machine or on the floor.
- You should think about how to efficiently explore the relationship between the objects and the machine.
- There are two rules that govern how objects turn on the machine: "disjunctive" and "conjunctive". You don't know which rule the machine follows a priori.
- If the rule is "disjunctive", the machine turns on when any of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- If the rule is "conjunctive", the machine only turns on when all of the blickets are placed on top of it.
- You should always consider first the hypothesis that all the blickets have to be on the machine for it to turn on (i.e. "conjunctive" rule). In this case, the objects required for the machine to turn on are all considered "blickets". You should consider this both when taking actions to uncover which objects are blickets, and when asked about it. 


You have 32 steps to complete the task. You can also exit the task early if you think you understand the relationship between the objects and the machine. After the task is done, you will be asked which objects are blickets, and the rule for turning on the machine.

You will be prompted at each turn to choose actions.
